model.name: San Francisco
model.description: Tech money may seem to be gentrifying every neighborhood of this former nexus of counter-culture, but San Francisco remains an incubator of innovation—and not just in the city's start-up offices. California Cuisine was born in the Bay Area, after all; and the world-class museums and cultural institutions rival any on the planet — remarkable for a city of fewer than a million people. The adventurous spirit that made San Francisco what it is today thrives in the new restaurants, cafes, shops and galleries sprinkled throughout what is, arguably, the most beautiful city in the U.S.
model.seoName: Things to Do in San Francisco: A Conde Nast Traveler Guide
model.seoDescription: Traveling to San Francisco? Conde Nast Traveler's guide to Chicago, Illinois provides the only information you need to know about where to stay, eat, and play.
model.socialName: San Francisco City Guide: Where to Eat, Stay, and Play
model.socialDescription: A complete guide to San Francisco, compiled by Conde Nast Traveler editors.
model.dontMiss:
###See###


[#activity: /activities/53eae5ad976f8f2d44d58b19]|||
The [DeYoung Museum](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/san-francisco/m-h-de-young-memorial-museum) is exhibiting the first Keith Haring show (titled, The Political Line) on the west coast in nearly two decades, through February 16.
|||






###Stay###


[#hotel: /hotels/53db0d35dcd5888e145dff72]|||
[Ritz-Carlton](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/san-francisco/ritz-carlton--san-francisco) is almost finished renovating its Neoclassical Nob Hill building (built in 1909). The lobby and common areas are finished, and all 336 guest rooms will be re-designed by March.
|||


###Eat###


[#restaurant: /restaurants/54947432228113ba47b5c73a]|||
Former Top Chef Masters winner Chris Cosentino just opened his new SoMa restaurant, [Cockscomb](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/san-francisco/cockscomb), in a former factory and will serve up twists on Cosentino's signature offal dishes. 
|||



###Shop###


[#shop: /shops/549474e3287bf30b36b420a3]|||
San Francisco-based [Spicer Bags](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/san-francisco/spicer-bags) opened its first retail space in the continually hip Dogpatch neighborhood, called Spicer on Third. It'll carry everything from their locally made bags to ceramics and jewelry.
|||


###FYI###


[#restaurant: /restaurants/5494756c976b7507578b0ce2]|||
The nation's juice craze hasn't skipped San Francisco, and the newest addition to the scene is [Project Juice](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/san-francisco/project-juice), on Valencia Street in the Mission. It'll also sell healthy grab-and-go options.   
|||

fields.bio: Senior Editor John Wogan has covered culture, food and travel news for *Conde Nast Traveler* since joining the magazine in 2012, and co-edits the annual Hot List. He previously worked at *Travel and Leisure* and *Town and Country.*

fields.name: Chaney Kwak
fields.shortBio: Chaney Kwak travels, eats, and writes.
fields.bio: In addition to Condé Nast Traveler, Chaney Kwak's writing appears in The Washington Post, Wall Street Journal, New York Times, Departures, Virtuoso Life, and National Geographic books. He is a co-author of the 2014 Fodor's Guide to Berlin.

featuredEats.name: La Nebbia
featuredEats.description: Located in San Francisco’s Noe Valley neighborhood, this Italian restaurant and wine bar opened in 2014 and was quickly noticed for its [__beautiful pizzas and its 14 kinds of prosciutto__](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-03-05/san-francisco-restaurant-la-nebbia-pizzas-prosciutto).
featuredEats.shortDescription: Located in San Francisco’s Noe Valley neighborhood, come for the pizzas and the prosciutto.

fields.caption: La Nebbia's squid ink, mozzarella, anchovy, raisin, and pine nut thin-crust pizza

featuredEats.name: Tosca
featuredEats.description: The historic Tosca Cafe opened in 1919 and still looks more or less the same, although its new owners (the folks behind The Spotted Pig in New York) have recently spruced the place up a bit and reintroduced food. The thinking man's celebrities—think Sean Penn and Francis Ford Coppola—tend to like this place, as do the city's literary celebs.
geoTags: North America/United States/Bay Area/California/San Francisco/North Beach
featuredEats.shortDescription: Come for duck-fat potato wedges and juicy chicken for two.

featuredEats.name: State Bird Provisions
featuredEats.description: It's a clever idea—American dishes served dimsum style--but State Bird Provisions is so much more than just clever. Husband-and-wife team executive chef Stuart Brioza and pastry chef Nicole Krasinski have created something really special here, and everyone from the James Beard Foundation to the Michelin board have taken notice. Make sure to try Brioza's signature fried quail, and save room for Krasinski's assortment of mini desserts.
geoTags: North America/United States/Bay Area/California/San Francisco/Western Addition
featuredEats.cuisine: Local or Regional, Haute Cuisine or Molecular Gastronomy, Eclectic or Global
featuredEats.shortDescription: At this dim sum style revival, don't miss Chef Brioza's notable fried quail.

featuredEats.name: Flour + Water
featuredEats.description: Few San Francisco restaurants better typify farm-to-table cooking than Flour + Water. The kitchen receives an entire pig every Tuesday—as well as a handful of small-game meats such as rabbit—and the chefs make use of the entire animal, making trotters, sausages, and fabulous salumi. Antipasti may include California sardines flash-fried in an elegantly light batter, served with a salty-tangy anchovy aïoli, while speck and balsamic-braised-radicchio pizzas are baked in a wood-fired oven that blisters the tender-to-the-tooth, thin crust with smoky bits of char; whole wheat strozzapreti comes tossed with hunks of perfectly cooked, licorice-hued anise-braised rabbit. The vibe is likewise dynamic and fresh, with linen dish towels serving as napkins on the exposed walnut tables. The restaurant is small, so it's best to book at least a week ahead, or expect a wait. Thankfully Flour + Water serves dinner until 11 pm weeknights and midnight weekends—a rarity in early-to-bed San Francisco.
featuredEats.shortDescription: Chef Thomas McNaughton will wow with his homemade pastas and creative thin-crust pizza combinations.

play.hed: 48 Hours in The Presidio of San Francisco
play.dek: The Presidio, San Francisco’s onetime military base turned national park, is home to one of the best little under-the-radar hotels in the Bay Area.

items.title: The Commissary
items.caption: In May, Traci Des Jardins (who’s behind the Hayes Valley neighborhood favorite Jardinière) opened The Commissary in this former barracks building, built in 1895.

The interior is bright, airy, and beautifully restrained, with design elements like reclaimed light fixtures from the surrounding historical buildings and Douglas fir table tops made of salvaged wood.

The restaurant serves as a canteen for lunch during the day, with grab-and-go sandwiches and charcuterie-and-cheese plates that can be taken out on the front porch overlooking the huge expanse of grassy lawn.
At dinner, the Spanish-influenced menu is filled with seafood and highlights local ingredients, like a seared mackerel with clams and fennel (pictured here).

items.title: The Team
items.caption: From left: Traci Des Jardins, Reylon Agustin (executive chef), Robbie Lewis (culinary director).

items.title: Inn at the Presidio
items.caption: Steps away from The Commissary is the 22-room Inn at the Presidio. Opened in 2012, it’s another meticulously restored building with a fire pit in the backyard and wooden rocking chairs out front.

Rooms look out over the Golden Gate Bridge and the bay, and the property has miles of eucalyptus-lined trails right outside the door. There’s no restaurant (and who needs it, with The Commissary so close by?) but there’s a complimentary breakfast every morning and a wine-and-cheese reception in the evenings.

items.title: Funston House
items.caption: Last summer, the Inn at the Presidio opened Funston House (at left), a stand-alone Victorian structure built in 1889, ideal for families or group of friends.
The entire house can be rented for $1,000 a night, which includes four bedrooms, a living room, dining room, and outdoor porches.

play.hed: Cool Kid-Friendly Activities in San Francisco You'll Love, Too
play.dek: Even San Francisco's kid-friendly activities are cooler than most cities'. Think chocolate-making tours and learning laboratories. Where can we sign up?
play.seoTitle: Cool Kid-Friendly Activities in San Francisco You'll Love, Too
play.seoDescription: Even San Francisco's kid-friendly activities are cooler than most cities'. Think chocolate-making tours and learning laboratories. Where can we sign up?
play.socialTitle: Cool Kid-Friendly Activities in San Francisco You'll Love, Too
play.socialDescription: Even San Francisco's kid-friendly activities are cooler than most cities'. Think chocolate-making tours and learning laboratories. Where can we sign up?
play.body:
[#image: /photos/53da9dbc6dec627b149f6f02]|||Baker Beach, San Francisco|||

With all its excellent [cocktail bars](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/10/best-san-francisco-cocktails), [charming cafes](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/01/iron-steam-espresso-bar-san-francisco), and [street food festivals](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/03/off-the-grid-street-fair-san-francisco), you already know San Francisco is a grown ups' playground. But the City by the Bay also happens to be one of the world's most kid-friendly cities, filled with cool activities that'll knock the socks off even the fussiest of miniature people. From chocolate-making tours to fun cultural activities, San Francisco has activities to keep your kids entertained for weeks (you might even find yourself having fun, too). Here are our favorites.







 **See the swans at the [Palace of Fine Arts](http://www.palaceoffinearts.org)**



 Sure, San Francisco Bay is nice, but the stunning lagoon outside the Palace of Fine Arts is worth its own excursion. There’s no admission fee to enjoy the grounds, and kids will love splashing in the running fountains and watching the longneck whooper swans that can be found paddling the water. _(3301 Lyon Street; 415-563-6504)_









[#image: /photos/53da9dbcdcd5888e145c0a3e]|||Witnessing the TCHO chocolate-making process|||

**Take a tour of the [TCHO Chocolate Factory](https://www.tcho.com/)**



 Family-friendly guided tours through this uber-cool chocolate warehouse include a short movie and a tasting of a few chocolate varieties. (Your first lesson: The name TCHO is derived from the first syllable of “chocolate"). The whole shebang takes just one hour—perfect for impatient kids—and they can even handle real cacao pods, and witness the massive choco-churning machines at work. The tour is free, but a $2 splurge buys you a fresh, molten shot of TCHO shot on your way out. _(Pier 17 on the Embarcadero; 415-81-0189)_







 **Play in the [Exploratorium](http://www.exploratorium.edu)**



 Your kids will be entertained for hours at this museum-cum-learning laboratory. Inside, you'll find six galleries and around 150 exhibits—many hands-on—spanning topics from astronomy to cooking. Outside the building, hitch a ride on the bike-powered Rickshaw Obscura for a kooky view of the city. _(Pier 15; 415-528-4360)_





[#image: /photos/53da9dbc6dec627b149f6f04]|||Sea Lions at Pier 39|||

**Watch the sea lions at [Pier 39](http://www.marinemammalcenter.org)**



 Ever since the 1989 earthquake struck the area, wild sea lions inexplicably arrived in droves to the Bay Area. Many can still be spotted sunbathing and “barking” outside the city’s Pier 39. Schedule a meet-up with an educator from the [Marine Mammal Center](http://www.marinemammalcenter.org/) to hear a one-hour guided introduction to what they eat, how they behave, and what the city is doing to keep them happy and safe. _(Beach Street and The Embarcadero; 415-981-7437)_























 **Picnic at [Baker Beach](http://www.yelp.com/biz/baker-beach-san-francisco)**



 The mile-long, secluded beach lies at the foot of rugged cliffs west of the Golden Gate. Many locals call it "the best beach in San Francisco," thanks to its unbeatable views of the bridge and the city. The water can get a little rough when it's windy, so keep your little ones close to shore and occupied with a picnic or volleyball game on the sand.







 **Ride the [Tiburon Ferry](http://www.blueandgoldfleet.com/)**



 Boat rides around the Bay are kind of a dime a dozen, but grab one that docks at Tiburon, a majestic former railroad town with panoramic views of San Francisco. (It’s often a haven from the fog, too). Opt to walk some or all of the Tiburon Historical Trail or stop off at the wildlife sanctuary or children’s fishing pier.

play.dek: Skip Golden Gate Park and Pier 39 this weekend. You'll have a better time with the locals at these awesome, non-touristy spots.

play.body:
[#image: /photos/53da9fb1dcd5888e145c1476]||||||


 We know, Golden Gate Park is nice and Pier 39 has its special charms (especially for those with [kids](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/03/kid-friendly-activities-san-francisco)). But on the weekends, these places are heavily congested with tourists and don't offer a taste of what the beautiful City by the Bay really has to offer. Consider the following, local-approved activities instead:







**Hike in the Cloud Forest:** One hundred years ago, the mayor of San Francisco had the genius idea to plant a forest right inside the San Francisco city walls. Now the [Mount Sutro Cloud Forest](http://mntsutro.com/) is an ethereal 80-acre oasis with trees towering up to 200 feet above a few well-carved walkways. Hiking one of the winding, well-shaded paths—deeply green at this time of year, and nearly always quiet—you will forget you’re even in a city.



**EAT Lunch at Tacolicious:** There are technically more "authentic" Mexican eateries in the city, but locals swear by [Tacolicious](http://tacolicious.com/). You won’t find burritos the size of your head here—offerings tend toward fresh and light (think ceviche, crudo tostadas, kale salads)—except, naturally, for the massive, overflowing basket of homemade tortilla chips that arrives at your table. (Warning. You _will _finish the whole thing). Take a cue from the name and try the tacos, particularly the traditional carnitas and braised short rib.

[#image: /photos/53da9fb16dec627b149f7866]|||Lake George with White Birch Georgia O’Keeffe (1921)|||

**See Georgia O’Keefe AT DE YOUNG:** Artist Georgia O’Keefe has been called one of the 20th centuries most important American painters, and as chances would have it, she also loved to travel. At the _Modern Nature: Georgia O’Keefe and Lake George_ exhibit, now on display at [de Young Museum](https://deyoung.famsf.org/), stroll through interpretations of her favorite scenery from the idyllic Lake George in New York. Of her time there, she had written to her friend: “I wish you could see the place here. There is something so perfect about the mountains and the lake and the trees, sometimes I want to tear it all to pieces, it seems so perfect.” This 55-piece collection recalls those very places she loved, scenes that will put you at ease and slow your spirit amidst the buzzing city.



**Enjoy Live Jazz AND PUNCH at the Burritt Room:** When night falls, head to the [Burritt Room](http://www.mystichotel.com/Eat-Drink/Burritt-Room) at Charlie Palmer’s Mystic Hotel. A dim-lit, dramatic tavern with a speakeasy vibe, it’s named after nearby Burritt alley (the very same spot Miles Archer was shot in _The Maltese Falcon_). A live jazz trio meets there every Saturday, and you can enjoy the tunes with a handful of friends around one of the house’s perfectly balanced punch bowls. Try the Bedlam, a champagne punch with fresh berries, or the Ay Papi, a tequila version with pineapple and lime.



Looking for more non-touristy activities in San Francisco? Don't worry—[we've got you covered](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/12/san-francisco-travel-ideas_slideshow_item0_1).

shop.body:
## It’s no secret that San Francisco is a world-class shopping destination, and has even been described as [“one giant outdoor shopping mall”](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/11/best-shopping-cities-world?s_cid=social_20131118_14613814) by some. But it’s more than just mall stores: the City by the Bay is replete with vintage shops, cool design stores, and flea markets, if you know where to look. We tapped one of San Francisco’s key tastemakers, **Victoria Smith**, for her insider's guide to shopping the city like a local.
[#image: /photos/53da8f7e6dec627b149f2e9b]|||The General Store|||
## The Expert


San Francisco tastemaker Victoria Smith is an expert at finding up-and-coming designers of all kinds, cool flea market pieces, and funky interior decor. Just ask the followers of her popular blog, [SF Girl By Bay](http://www.sfgirlbybay.com/), which garners over 25,000 clicks a day. And it's no wonder: Smith herself worked a number of creative jobs involving photography and home staging before realizing her ability to condense her design genius into a few perfectly curated posts a day. The posts rotate among virtual tours, artist and artisan spotlights, lust-worthy products, and DIY designs from all over the world. Here, she pares down her go-to shops in San Francisco to a few of her favorites.



 


##



Victoria Smith’s Favorite Stores in San Francisco






**[General Store](http://shop-generalstore.com/)**



 “I love the vintage vibe of this surfer-chic shop, well curated with loads of unique home accessories, objects d’art, books, jewelry, clothing and really cool succulents. There’s even a wee greenhouse designed by visual artist Jesse Schlesinger out back, that owners artist Serena Mitnik-Miller and architect Mason St. Peter appear to be constantly upgrading.”











**[Nest](http://www.nestsf.com)**



 “One of my very favorite haunts in the city, Nest is quite like a French flea market with multi-cultural, cosmopolitan flair. This eclectic shop on Fillmore Street carries gorgeous home decor accessories with a unique, vintage look. The tiny shop is filled with beautiful Moroccan throws, handmade pillows, and glassware—a lot of pretty things you might not need, but you will definitely want.”







**[Heath Ceramics](http://www.heathceramics.com)**



 “One of my favorite mid-century modern ceramic shops from Sausalito, just over the Golden Gate bridge, finally has a location in San Francisco. Every piece of Heath’s ceramic dishware is still made in their original factory in Sausalito, and crafted in the same beautiful manner as it has been since 1948. The new city showroom is gorgeous and is also the home of their tile manufacturing facility. The space also includes a café that serves [Blue Bottle Coffee](http://www.bluebottlecoffee.com/), the favorite of San Francisco coffee connoisseurs, all served, of course, in Heath's own ceramic cups.”







**[Stuff](http://www.stuffsf.com)**



 “Stuff is a vintage collective of more than 25 dealers who do the dirty work of navigating estate sales and flea markets to find essential design goods for the rest of us. The shop carries vintage furniture, clothing, jewelry and décor and their stuff spans the range of iconic modern design eras, from art deco to mid-century styles, mod to atomic. The goods are all displayed in 8,200 square feet of easy-to-navigate awesomeness, plus the owners play really good music and offer free parking.”







**[The Perish Trust](http://www.theperishtrust.com)**



 “This is a tiny gem of a shop in the up and coming Nopa neighborhood. Dedicated to showcasing upcycled and repurposed industrial-chic accessories and housewares, owners Rod Hipsking and Kelly Ishikawa hunt down odd and unusual finds from artists across the country, then display them in their gallery-like space. They’re also the home of Warby Parker’s eyeglasses, and the only place in San Francisco you can find them and try them on in person. You need to check their hours before going though—they keep some independent hours.”



 


## Victoria’s Souvenir Finds
[#image: /photos/53da8f7edcd5888e145bcb8d]|||“[Mill Mercantile](http://www.millmercantile.com) is a women’s clothing shop right in my own neighborhood—Noe Valley—that carries apothecary items and housewares, too. Much of the styling is reminiscent of menswear: think oxford shirt-dresses and oxford shoes. They also carry a very limited edition collection of vintage reproduction clothing from San Francisco-based [Levi Strauss & Co.](http://www.millmercantile.com/Levi_s_Vintage_Clothing_Womens.html) (the historical originals from Levi's San Francisco archives dating back to 1880). I have their [1950's Fringed Suede Jacket](http://www.millmercantile.com/Levi_s_Vintage_Clothing_1950s_Fringed_Leather_Jacket_in_Brown_Suede_12367.html) on my wish list.”|||

[#image: /photos/53da8f7e6dec627b149f2e9f]|||“I love this artsy boutique full of one of a kind gifts, home accessories and artwork in NOPA, aptly called [Rare Device](http://raredevice.net/). Owner Giselle Gyalzen carries all kinds of handmade goods from local San Francisco makers, and I've especially been eying this [Bundlenecklace](http://raredevice.net/collections/jewelry/products/bundle-pendant-necklace) from jewelry designer [Shana Astrachan](http://www.shanaastrachan.com/home.html). The storefront operates as a gallery, too, showcasing local artists and hosting community events like book signings, workshops and trunk shows.”|||

[#image: /photos/53da8f7edcd5888e145bcb8f]|||“The ultimate of San Francisco one-of-a-kind shops is author Dave Eggar’s eclectic [826 Valencia Pirate Shop](http://826valencia.org/store/). If you visit, you simply must purchase an [eye patch](http://826valencia.org/store/products/eye-patch/), because everyone knows no pirate would be complete without one. Proceeds from sales go to support non-profit writing tutoring programs: In house and in classrooms all over San Francisco, 826 Valencia supports students ages six to eighteen on their creative writing skills and promotes teachers to keep inspiring them.”|||

[#image: /photos/53da8f7e6dec627b149f2e9d]|||“[Bi-Rite](http://www.biritemarket.com/) is the ultimate San Francisco gourmet market, also known for their amazing [Bi-Rite Creamery](http://biritecreamery.com/) ice cream shop and [18 Reasons](http://www.18reasons.org/), a space where they host gastronomical community classes of all kinds including canning, sushi-making and wine pairing. They came out with their own cookbook, [Eat Good Food,  A Grocer’s Guide to Shopping, Cooking & Creating Community Through Food](http://www.biritemarket.com/book/), designed to help you shop and eat smarter and focus on locally-grown, sustainable foods. So far I've found the recipes to be fool-proof.’|||

shop.hed: This San Francisco Chocolate Shop Puts Willy Wonka to Shame
shop.dek: Vacation is the perfect time to indulge in things you might not do in your daily life, like eat high-end chocolate or spending hours flipping through magazines. One San Francisco shop helps you do both at once.
shop.seoTitle: This San Francisco Chocolate Shop Puts Willy Wonka to Shame
shop.seoDescription: Vacation is the perfect time to indulge in things you might not do in your daily life, like eat high-end chocolate or spending hours flipping through magazines. One San Francisco shop helps you do both at once.
shop.socialTitle: This San Francisco Chocolate Shop Puts Willy Wonka to Shame
shop.socialDescription: Vacation is the perfect time to indulge in things you might not do in your daily life, like eat high-end chocolate or spending hours flipping through magazines. One San Francisco shop helps you do both at once.
shop.body:
[#image: /photos/53daa5dbdcd5888e145c27fe]||||||

If your idea of a heavenly vacation includes lazing around, flipping through magazines while indulging in exotic chocolate, then San Francisco’s [Fog City News](http://www.fogcitynews.com/home.html) is the shop for you. Open since 1999, the store—situated on bustling Market Street—has a simple but brilliant concept: Owner Adam Smith stocks more than 200 varieties of chocolate, along with more than 3,000 magazine titles. “I wanted to create a store environment that would make people reconsider the notion of the traditional newsstand,” Smith explains.







So what will you find there? Let’s start with the chocolate, the selection of which takes up nearly half the store. Approximately 50 percent of the stock is imported, while the rest is from U.S. chocolatiers. The shop is packed with classic goodies (like milk chocolate, or dark chocolate with nuts), but also has wide selection of quirkier items. One popular confection from Columbia, Missouri’s Patric (which took home gold medals in the International Chocolate Awards last year) contains coconut, chiles, and ginger—like a red coconut curry in a bar. Or try something from Sacramento’s Ginger Elizabeth chocolates: The founder models her bars after her favorite desserts, like crepes.





[#image: /photos/53daa5dbdcd5888e145c27fc]||||||

A sugar crash may be inevitable, but before that hits, wander over to the magazine stands and browse for a bit. “I’ve always said, For every interest that exists, there is a magazine for it,” Smith explains. “When customers slow down and look at what we offer, they begin to see that every magazine category has more breadth to it than they might have originally thought.” Although the shop doesn’t specialize in any one genre, Smith says the most popular publications focus on food, design, and fashion. And there’s plenty to choose from: Among the hundreds of titles, you’ll find some of the usual suspects like _GQ_ and _Vogue_, as well as oddballs like _Road Book_, a luxury men’s mag, and _Smith Journal_, an Australian quarterly; international mags are also a hit with readers.



_455 Market St; 415-543-7400, [fogcitynews.com](http://fogcitynews.com)_

Photos: Stacy Adimando

The next time you're in San Francisco, follow this surefire plan for a day of feasting and fun courtesy of [Fellow Barber owner Sam Buffa](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/12/gift-ideas-for-men).



 

[#image: /photos/53da8dd66dec627b149f2814]|||The waves at Ocean Beach, a favorite surfing spot of Buffa and Tartine baker Chad Robertson|||

**[ ](http://www.parksconservancy.org/visit/park-sites/ocean-beach.html)**



**[Ride the waves at Ocean Beach](http://www.parksconservancy.org/visit/park-sites/ocean-beach.html)**



"What other major city has an almost four-mile stretch of sandy beaches and dunes with world-class surf? While not known for sunny days, if you are there during Indian summer, you can find 70-plus degree days and surf that can rival any break in the world."

[#image: /photos/53da8dd66dec627b149f2812]|||Fresh loaves at Tartine|||

**[ ](http://www.tartinebakery.com)**



**[Break bread at Tartine](http://www.tartinebakery.com)**



"Not that everyone doesn't already know about this spot, but [Tartine really perfected artisanal](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/10/photos-todd-selby-food-photography-book-edible-selby-101012_slideshow_item4_5), before it was cool. Chad Robertson is a master baker with a whole lot of skill and creativity, and it shows in the product. Since he opened shop, there have been a bunch of knockoffs who quit their jobs at Google and decided to start making bread six months ago."

[#image: /photos/53da8dd6dcd5888e145bc4ec]|||Paxton Gate, a taxidermy and curiosity shop|||

**[ ](http://www.paxtongate.com)**



**[Shop for curiosities at Paxton Gate](http://www.paxtongate.com)**



"If I'm wandering around on Valencia Street, I can't help but stop by this original neighborhood standout. It's like a nature lover's one-stop shop that has been selling taxidermy and curiosities for over 20 years now. They have a magical backyard that showcases their landscape design offerings too."

[#image: /photos/53da8dd66dec627b149f2810]|||Buffa’s favorite Mexican joint is La Tacqueria|||

 



 



****



**Chow down at La Taqueria**



"Just the best Mexican you will ever have. Hands down." (2889 Mission Street; 415-285-7117)





[#image: /photos/53da8dd6dcd5888e145bc4ea]|||The recently revived San Francisco bar Tosca|||

 



**[Drink at Tosca](http://toscacafesf.com)**



This bar is "a San Francisco classic that was recently revived by industry vets, Ken Friedman and April Bloomfield. It's rare when people can see beauty in a place that is almost 100 years old. They added to its greatness by updating the menu while holding true to what people were eating and drinking in 1919."

featuredShops.name: Amoeba Music
featuredShops.description: A music junkie's paradise, Amoeba has an encyclopedic selection of new and used CDs, as well as DVDs, music posters, LPs, and 45s. Everyone from pierced club kids to aging Deadheads comes here to offload their used CDs for cash or trade them and then stay for hours to browse. Unlike Virgin and other media mega-stores, Amoeba has an extremely knowledgeable and helpful staff, many of whom moonlight as musicians or DJs. Plus, there are live in-store performances every week (sometimes local bands, sometimes major phenoms like DJ Shadow).
featuredShops.shortDescription: A music junkie's paradise; find here new and used CDs, DVDs, music posters, LPs, and 45s.

featuredShops.name: City Lights Bookstore
featuredShops.description: The Beat writers turned City Lights into their home base in San Francisco, and the North Beach bookstore, established in 1953 by Lawrence Ferlinghetti, continues to be a mecca for writers who dream of leaving behind something more substantial than blog entries. City Lights is a reminder of what an independent bookstore provides that Amazon cannot: a curated selection of unexpected titles that reflect the literary tastes of the store's owners and managers. Go, and be prepared to leave with a book you'd never heard of before walking in.
featuredShops.shortDescription: Explore City Light Bookstore's curated selection of unexpected titles.

featuredShops.name: Heath Ceramics
featuredShops.description: Mid-Century Modern ceramicist Edith Heath started Heath Ceramics in 1948 and the company has continued to design and manufacture her designs, along with new products by modern-day owners Catherine Bailey and Robin Petravic, who bought the company from then-93-year-old Heath back in 2004. At that time, the Heath factory in Sausalito was run down and many people had forgotten about Heath Ceramics; Bailey and Petravic have brought the name back in a big way, a decade-long process that culminated in the 2013 opening of a beautiful San Francisco factory, complete with a light and airy showroom, tile-making factory, and Blue Bottle café. These days the company is as well known for its architectural tiles as for its cups, saucers, bowls, and vases.This stuff ain't cheap, but it will last forever, and every visitor to your house will want to know where it came from and how to get it.
featuredShops.shortDescription: This SF factory is complete with a light and airy showroom, tile-making factory, and Blue Bottle café.

featuredShops.name: New People
featuredShops.description: If a trip to Tokyo isn't in your budget, New People in Japantown offers four floors of Japanese products, with fashion that runs the gamut from Lolita to punk, plus stationery, toys, and gadgets in a rainbow of candy colors, often adorned with smiley faces. In the store's basement, Viz Cinema has a changing lineup of new Japanese films.
featuredShops.shortDescription: This Japantown boutique offers four floors of all-you-want Japanese lifestyle brands.

pinterest.hed: 48 Hours in The Presidio of San Francisco
pinterest.dek: The Presidio, San Francisco’s onetime military base turned national park, is home to one of the best little under-the-radar hotels in the Bay Area.

items.title: The Commissary
items.caption: In May, Traci Des Jardins (who’s behind the Hayes Valley neighborhood favorite Jardinière) opened The Commissary in this former barracks building, built in 1895.

The interior is bright, airy, and beautifully restrained, with design elements like reclaimed light fixtures from the surrounding historical buildings and Douglas fir table tops made of salvaged wood.

The restaurant serves as a canteen for lunch during the day, with grab-and-go sandwiches and charcuterie-and-cheese plates that can be taken out on the front porch overlooking the huge expanse of grassy lawn.
At dinner, the Spanish-influenced menu is filled with seafood and highlights local ingredients, like a seared mackerel with clams and fennel (pictured here).

items.title: The Team
items.caption: From left: Traci Des Jardins, Reylon Agustin (executive chef), Robbie Lewis (culinary director).

items.title: Inn at the Presidio
items.caption: Steps away from The Commissary is the 22-room Inn at the Presidio. Opened in 2012, it’s another meticulously restored building with a fire pit in the backyard and wooden rocking chairs out front.

Rooms look out over the Golden Gate Bridge and the bay, and the property has miles of eucalyptus-lined trails right outside the door. There’s no restaurant (and who needs it, with The Commissary so close by?) but there’s a complimentary breakfast every morning and a wine-and-cheese reception in the evenings.

items.title: Funston House
items.caption: Last summer, the Inn at the Presidio opened Funston House (at left), a stand-alone Victorian structure built in 1889, ideal for families or group of friends.
The entire house can be rented for $1,000 a night, which includes four bedrooms, a living room, dining room, and outdoor porches.

pinterest.hed: The Perfect Weekend in San Francisco
pinterest.dek: Skip Golden Gate Park and Pier 39 this weekend. You'll have a better time with the locals at these awesome, non-touristy spots.
pinterest.seoTitle: The Perfect Weekend in San Francisco
pinterest.seoDescription: Skip Golden Gate Park and Pier 39 this weekend. You'll have a better time with the locals at these awesome, non-touristy spots.
pinterest.socialTitle: The Perfect Weekend in San Francisco
pinterest.socialDescription: Skip Golden Gate Park and Pier 39 this weekend. You'll have a better time with the locals at these awesome, non-touristy spots.
pinterest.body:
[#image: /photos/53da9fb1dcd5888e145c1476]||||||


 We know, Golden Gate Park is nice and Pier 39 has its special charms (especially for those with [kids](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/03/kid-friendly-activities-san-francisco)). But on the weekends, these places are heavily congested with tourists and don't offer a taste of what the beautiful City by the Bay really has to offer. Consider the following, local-approved activities instead:







**Hike in the Cloud Forest:** One hundred years ago, the mayor of San Francisco had the genius idea to plant a forest right inside the San Francisco city walls. Now the [Mount Sutro Cloud Forest](http://mntsutro.com/) is an ethereal 80-acre oasis with trees towering up to 200 feet above a few well-carved walkways. Hiking one of the winding, well-shaded paths—deeply green at this time of year, and nearly always quiet—you will forget you’re even in a city.



**EAT Lunch at Tacolicious:** There are technically more "authentic" Mexican eateries in the city, but locals swear by [Tacolicious](http://tacolicious.com/). You won’t find burritos the size of your head here—offerings tend toward fresh and light (think ceviche, crudo tostadas, kale salads)—except, naturally, for the massive, overflowing basket of homemade tortilla chips that arrives at your table. (Warning. You _will _finish the whole thing). Take a cue from the name and try the tacos, particularly the traditional carnitas and braised short rib.

[#image: /photos/53da9fb16dec627b149f7866]|||Lake George with White Birch Georgia O’Keeffe (1921)|||

**See Georgia O’Keefe AT DE YOUNG:** Artist Georgia O’Keefe has been called one of the 20th centuries most important American painters, and as chances would have it, she also loved to travel. At the _Modern Nature: Georgia O’Keefe and Lake George_ exhibit, now on display at [de Young Museum](https://deyoung.famsf.org/), stroll through interpretations of her favorite scenery from the idyllic Lake George in New York. Of her time there, she had written to her friend: “I wish you could see the place here. There is something so perfect about the mountains and the lake and the trees, sometimes I want to tear it all to pieces, it seems so perfect.” This 55-piece collection recalls those very places she loved, scenes that will put you at ease and slow your spirit amidst the buzzing city.



**Enjoy Live Jazz AND PUNCH at the Burritt Room:** When night falls, head to the [Burritt Room](http://www.mystichotel.com/Eat-Drink/Burritt-Room) at Charlie Palmer’s Mystic Hotel. A dim-lit, dramatic tavern with a speakeasy vibe, it’s named after nearby Burritt alley (the very same spot Miles Archer was shot in _The Maltese Falcon_). A live jazz trio meets there every Saturday, and you can enjoy the tunes with a handful of friends around one of the house’s perfectly balanced punch bowls. Try the Bedlam, a champagne punch with fresh berries, or the Ay Papi, a tequila version with pineapple and lime.



Looking for more non-touristy activities in San Francisco? Don't worry—[we've got you covered](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/12/san-francisco-travel-ideas_slideshow_item0_1).

pinterest.dek: From chocolate beer ice cream to made-from-scratch s'mores, this is why everyone leaves their heart in San Francisco.
pinterest.hed: A Chocolate Lover's Guide to San Francisco

items.title: [Chocolate Beer Ice Cream](http://www.humphryslocombe.com/www.humphryslocombe.com/Home.html)
items.caption: This might seem like the average Mission District ice creamery when you walk through the door, but one peek into the freezer case will have you eating your words. Their inventive, chocolate-based flavor offerings change regularly, but the two currently on offer are some of the most delicious we've tried. One is made with a chocolate porter from Almanac brewing company and stuffed with dark chocolate chips, while the second flavor is made with milk chocolate and malt. Get this combo atop a cone, which many say are the best in the city.

items.title: [Chocolate Croissant Stack ](http://www.craftsman-wolves.com)
items.caption: Trying to choose just one chocolate treat at this super hip bakery-cafe is, well, torture. Let us explain: Their version of San Francisco's signature sourdough bread is laced with cocoa and chocolate chips. Similarly, their breakfast carrot cake muffin comes flavored with cocoa and features a crumb topping, while their "traditional" croissant is shaped like a towering square and stuffed with chocolate (and topped with it). Need we say more?

items.title: [Chocolate Truffle Tart ](ttps://www.miette.com/mailorder/confections/fleur-de-sel-caramels)
items.caption: Though many locals choose Miette for its pretty packaging and whimsical treats, the shop’s filled with glass candy jars and perfectly piped cupcakes—the chocolate ganache tart alone shows this bakery is worth its gourmet salt. The shop makes 20 gallons of ganache each week, using it as a glaze for eclairs and a filling for macarons too, but these tiny tarts pack the highest concentration of it per bite. The French sea salt finish puts it over the top. Splitting one is the best kind of messy.

items.title: [The House S’Mores](http://www.dandelionchocolate.com)
items.caption: That whole campfire thing doesn’t happen at Dandelion Chocolate, but you won’t miss it much when you’re digging into their signature s’mores. Nothing comes out of a plastic bag or paper sleeve here: graham crackers are made from scratch and have a perfectly crumbly consistency, marshmallows receive an ideal amount of char, and the chocolate is made from hand-roasted, smoke-dried cocoa beans from Papua New Guinea that are naturally smoky. Plus, each s’more is toasted to order.

items.title: [Chocolate Shake](http://www.stfrancisfountainsf.com)
items.caption:
There are plenty of places to get a milkshake in San Francisco, but none half as charming inside as St. Francis Fountain. This old-fashioned diner and dessert bar is the real deal: Established in 1918, it’s the city’s oldest soda shop. While the menu offers no shortage of throwback chocolate offerings, like black and white shakes, egg creams, and hot fudge sundaes, the chocolate milkshake is a perfect dose of nostalgia, with chocolate ice cream, a hefty dose of chocolate syrup, and a splash of milk. Thanks to the two straws, it’s also perfect for sharing—not that you'll want to.




**More on San Francisco food:**




[Skip In-N-Out. This is Where to Get Your Burgers on the West Coast](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/01/roam-burger-san-francisco )[](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/01/iron-steam-espresso-bar-san-francisco )




[The One Drink You Should Have in SF and Where to Get It](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/01/iron-steam-espresso-bar-san-francisco )







[These Food Photos Will Make You Want to Book a Ticket to SF, Now](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/10/what-to-eat-san-francisco-fall-restaurants-fog-city-ame-rich-table_slideshow_item0_1)

pinterest.dek: With its fog-swept streets and gothic architecture, San Francisco was a perfect match for Alfred Hitchcock. Here, we tour some of the locations-turned-landmarks that inspired the Master of Suspense.
pinterest.hed: In Their Shoes: Alfred Hitchcock’s San Francisco

items.caption: Alfred Hitchcock may have been born in London, but the legendary filmmaker’s formidable career eventually landed him in California, where he quickly fell in love with San Francisco. With its fog-swept streets and Gothic-inspired architecture, the City by the Bay was the perfect geographic match for The Master of Suspense, as evidenced by the many films he shot in the area (_Vertigo, Family Plot, _and _The Birds _among them). As we roll up on what would have been Hitch's 115th birthday this summer (on August 13th), we’re taking a look back at the San Francisco locations that inspired him and still stand as city landmarks today.

items.title: [Fort Point](http://www.nps.gov/fopo/index.htm)
items.caption: Of all the many movies Hitch filmed (at least partially) in San Francisco, _Vertigo_ might be the most famous. The romantic thriller stars James Stewart as Scottie, a retired detective hired to spy on Madeleine (Kim Novak), the enigmatic wife of an old college friend who the husband believes is possessed. Their initial introduction comes when Scottie is forced to play hero after Madeleine hurls herself into San Francisco Bay from Fort Point, a Civil War-era model in master masonry meant to protect the city from a naval attack. It also just happens to have one of the city’s most breathtaking views of the [**Golden Gate Bridge**](http://www.goldengatebridge.org/). Just don’t waste your time looking for the stairs that Scottie uses to carry Madeleine out of the water; they were built for the film (and promptly removed).

items.title: [Top of the Mark](http://www.intercontinentalmarkhopkins.com/top-of-the-mark.aspx)
items.caption: In the beginning of _Vertigo_, Scottie remarks that his affliction means, "I can't go to the bar at the Top of the Mark, but there are plenty of street level bars in this town." But the 75-year-old bar, located on the 19th floor of the [InterContinental Mark Hopkins San Francisco](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/intercontinental-mark-hopkins-san-francisco-san-francisco-california), is worth the journey skyward—if not for the 360-degree panoramic views of the city, then for its 100 Martinis menu.

items.title: [Coit Tower](http://sfrecpark.org/destination/telegraph-hill-pioneer-park/coit-tower/)
items.caption: Though the interior of Scottie’s apartment was filmed on a soundstage, Hitchcock was adamant that the 210-foot Coit Tower, which looms large over the city, appear in the background of his window. Visitors looking to reach the top of the tower need only buy a ticket and hop an elevator to the observation deck, offering 360-degree views of the city. The tower, named for local benefactor Lillie Hitchcock Coit (no relation), was constructed in 1933 and is one of the city’s most recognizable structures. But according to the late Henry Bumstead, _Vertigo_’s art director, Hitchcock’s insistence on featuring the tower went beyond posterity. "When I asked why, he said, 'It’s a phallic symbol,'" [**Bumstead once told a gathering of UCLA students**](http://hitchcock.zone/wiki/The_Daily_Bruin_%2826/Nov/2002%29_-_Bumstead_gives_talk_on_art_direction,_Vertigo).

items.title: [Legion of Honor](https://legionofhonor.famsf.org/)
items.caption: When Madeline visits the Legion of Honor, part of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, she’s focused on just one painting. But it would be easy to spend an entire afternoon in this Beaux Arts building in Lincoln Park, which was constructed in honor of Californian soldiers who died during World War I. The museum houses an impressive display of ancient and European art dating back 4,000 years, including Rodin’s _Thinker_ in the courtyard. It also boasts fantastic views of the Pacific Ocean, Golden Gate Bridge and San Francisco at large.
items.credit: © Craig Lovell / Eagle Visions Photography / Alamy

items.title: [Hotel Vertigo](http://www.haiyi-hotels.com/hotelvertigosf/)
items.caption: This playful Nob Hill hotel played a role in _Vertigo_—Madeleine was a guest there, in room 401—although it was then known as the Empire Hotel. Today, the 102-room boutique hotel plays up its ties to Hitch with a bright orange color scheme, reminiscent of the film’s well-known movie poster, and odes to its famous orange swirl as wall art.

items.title: [Argonaut Book Shop](http://www.argonautbookshop.com/)
items.caption: Though The Argosy Book Shop that appears in _Vertigo _is a fictional place, it is based on a real one—the 73-year-old Argonaut Book Shop in the city’s financial district. Impressed by the shop’s warm wooden interiors and dizzying mezzanine, Hitchcock and his team visited and photographed the store, then re-created it for the film. But one little-known fact is that, even with his replicated set, Hitch shot a bit of the film in the store itself.

items.title: [Union Square](http://www.unionsquareshop.com/)
items.caption: One of Fog City’s most popular landmarks—a 2.6-acre public plaza that’s surrounded by some of the city’s most popular boutiques, eateries, hotels, and cultural institutions—makes a brief appearance at the beginning of _The Birds_, when Melanie Daniels (Tippi Hedren) notices a swarm of birds flying above the square before entering a pet shop.

items.title: [Foreign Cinema](http://www.foreigncinema.com)
items.caption:
Hitch passed away nearly 20 years before this hybrid restaurant/cinema/art gallery/nightclub opened in 1999, but we’re pretty sure he’d approve of the industrial-style outdoor courtyard that screens foreign and independent films on a nightly basis.




 




**More things to do in San Francisco: **




[A Chocolate Lover's Guide to San Francisco](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/02/san-francisco-chocolate-guide)




[What Not To Do In San Francisco](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/12/san-francisco-travel-ideas)




[The Cocktails You Must Drink In San Francisco](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/10/best-san-francisco-cocktails)

fields.name: Jennifer M. Wood
fields.shortBio: Jennifer M. Wood is a freelance writer and editor who divides her time between New York City, Miami, and Cape Cod.
fields.bio: Jennifer M. Wood writes about travel, food, film, television, pop culture, technology, art, and beer. In addition to Condé Nast Traveler, her work has appeared in *Wired, Mental Floss, Esquire, Details, Rolling Stone, Men's Journal, Departures, American Way, Draft, Complex*, and *Time Out New York*. She is the former Editor-in-Chief of *MovieMaker Magazine* and the Editor of the sixth edition of *Time Out Miami*.

miniGuides.hed: The Perfect Day in San Francisco
miniGuides.dek: Set against roller-coaster-worthy hills and a glittering bay, San Francisco is California at its romantic best, combining the West Coast’s natural abundance with cultural diversity. And in this fast-paced epicenter of the tech world, you can experience a whole lot in just three hours.
miniGuides.body:
[#image: /photos/5490820f860c74c1162ca431]|||
San Francisco's famous Painted Ladies, as seen from Alamo Square.
|||




##PLAY HERE


Kick back at __[Alamo Square](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/san-francisco/alamo-square)__, a hilltop park where you’ll get a perfect (and iconic) view of the Painted Ladies—the city’s famed pastel Victorian-style wooden houses, as seen in the opening credits of *Full House*—against the backdrop of downtown’s steel-and-glass skyscrapers. 


##SHOP HERE

A ten-minute downhill walk will take you to the reigning epicenter of SF cool, __[Hayes Valley](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/san-francisco/hayes-valley)__. In Hayes Street’s indie boutiques, you’ll find everything from messenger bags to one-of-a-kind furniture. [__Triple Aught Design__](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/francisco/triple-aught-design), which manufactures durable and functional wear like agile, modular jackets and streamlined pants with hidden pockets, attracts both road warriors and real-life ones (the store counts special-ops agents in its loyal fan base); [__Lavish__](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/san-francisco/lavish) champions Bay Area designers such as [__Yellow Howl Workshop__](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/san-francisco/yellow-howl-workshop), a playful designer of colorful stationery and bold pendants; and three months ago, Berkeley’s [__Convert__](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/san-francisco/convert) opened a location here, selling preppy Oxfords, American-made denim, and other casual clothes that make the man.


[#image: /photos/548b597bb6e03e8c2d0cc262]|||
Chefs Evan and Sarah Rich craft delicious farm-to-table fare at Rich Table.|||





##EAT HERE

With its salvaged barnwood décor and hyperlocal ingredients, [__Rich Table__](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/san-francisco/rich-table) embodies the northern California culinary scene’s farm-to-table rabidity. Here you’ll find ingenious dishes that the chefs brainstorm while hiking, like octopus confit with broccoli rabe, and sea scallops with smoked quince and fermented fish sauce.
miniGuides.seoDescription: A trip to San Francisco needn't be overwhelming—you can pack a lot into three hours, including a farm-to-table meal and one of the city's prettiest parks.
miniGuides.socialDescription: A trip to San Francisco needn't be overwhelming—you can pack a lot into three hours, including a farm-to-table meal and one of the city's prettiest parks.

fields.name: Chaney Kwak
fields.shortBio: Chaney Kwak travels, eats, and writes.
fields.bio: In addition to Condé Nast Traveler, Chaney Kwak's writing appears in The Washington Post, Wall Street Journal, New York Times, Departures, Virtuoso Life, and National Geographic books. He is a co-author of the 2014 Fodor's Guide to Berlin.

miniGuides.hed: The Perfect Weekend in San Francisco
miniGuides.dek: Even though San Francisco has undergone massive changes as of late (thanks to an infusion of Silicon Valley money), it hasn't lost all of its quirky charm. Here's how to spend a perfect weekend in San Francisco.
miniGuides.body:
[#image: /photos/548b61d8b6e03e8c2d0cc351]||||||




Put historic Victorian homes, cutting-edge startups, old-time hippies, and people from every corner of the world onto a seven-by-seven mile peninsula, and what do you have? San Francisco. Every neighborhood here has a different flavor, so whether you want to wear flowers in your hair or raise capital for your next venture, there’s a place for you to go. 


[#image: /photos/548b61d0860c74c1162c9174]|||
Ai Weiwei's exhibit at Alcatraz is reason enough to pay a visit to San Francisco.
|||





##DAY 1: EMBARCADERO/DOWNTOWN/NORTH BEACH

__PLAY: Alcatraz__

The famed islet is no longer a federal penitentiary, nor is it just an over-visited tourist magnet, thanks to the latest site-specific [__Ai Weiwei installations__](http://www.nps.gov/goga/planyourvisit/aiweiwei.htm). Unveiled in September 2014, the seven pieces of sculpture, mixed-media pieces, and sound installations are integrated into cell blocks, prison infirmary, and the New Industries Building, a 1939 structure that was off-limits to visitors until the exhibition. Keep your camera in hand during the ferry rides from and to Pier 33—the views are spectacular.

__EAT__

Some clichés are in fact true: San Franciscans are obsessed with food, and the popular Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday farmers’ market at the [__Ferry Building__](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/san-francisco/ferry-building-marketplace) is a prime location to watch the local inhabitants graze and forage. Noteworthy brick-and-mortar shops available throughout the week include: [__Cowgirl Creamery__](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/san-francisco/cowgirl-creamery), famous for its woodsy triple cream, Mt. Tam; [__Slanted Door__](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/san-francisco/slanted-door), where you should order the caramelized catfish claypot; and [__Acme Bread__](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/san-francisco/acme-bread), credited for popularizing rustic, hand-crafted loaves in the Bay Area.

__EXPLORE__ 

Yes, every visitor does it; yes, so should you. Hop on the [__Powell-Hyde streetcar__](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/san-francisco/powell-hyde-streetcar) and explore the city’s rolling topography. The dozen-block stretch on Hyde Street is one of the world’s most enticing cable car rides, with colorful buildings scrolling by as the trolley races up and down the street.

__EAT__ 

Thanks to a large Asian population, the city has some of the best Chinese food in the country. The beloved downtown [__Yank Sing__](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/san-francisco/yank-sing) serves some 60 varieties of authentic (like traditional siu mai and har gow) and novel (think bacon-wrapped shrimp and scallion) dim sum dishes in two locations (just a few blocks apart from each other). 

__SHOP__ 

Near the legendary [__City Lights Bookstore__](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/san-francisco/city-lights-bookstore) (which published the acclaimed Pocket Poets series that included bards like Frank O’Hara, and still serves as the center of San Francisco literary life) is the miniscule [__Beat Museum__](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/san-francisco/beat-museum), a tribute to Jack Kerouac and his friends. Here you can see Allen Ginsberg’s typewriter, rare editions of prose and poetry by Kerouac, Ginsberg, and William S. Burroughs, and a souvenir shop that features, among others, Beat poet bobbleheads.

__EAT__

The North Beach restaurant [__Coi__](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/san-francisco/coi) is a local icon, its dozen-course tasting menu celebrating the state’s flora and fauna (and many other ingredients). Get a “ticket” beforehand—prices fluctuating depending on the time of the day—and let Daniel Patterson, the 2014 James Beard Foundation best chef, dazzle you with dishes like steamed black trumpet and sunchoke dumplings and tender beef cooked rare and encrusted in seaweed powder.

__DRINK__ 

If you have any leftover energy, stop for a nightcap at [__Tosca Café__](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/san-francisco/tosca-cafe), a near-century-old dive bar reborn as a smart bistro at the hands of New York restaurateurs April Bloomfield and Ken Friedman in 2013. The food menu is brand new, but the old-world ambiance lives on, thanks to the painstaking restoration of the original space, which features a 1930s mural of Venice on the back wall and checkerboard tiles. The 1920s espresso machine adds to the atmosphere—but doesn’t contribute to the bar’s Prohibition Era signature drink, a caffeine-free “cappuccino” made with bourbon and chocolate ganache. 



[#image: /photos/5490841db6e03e8c2d0cd75d]|||
Mission Dolores 
|||



##DAY 2: The Mission

Long before the Mission became synonymous with hipster culture, the area was home to an 18th-century Spanish mission. __[Mission Dolores](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/san-franciso/mission-dolores)__ continues to serve as a place of worship, drawing congregants of all walks of life. Admire the beautiful gardens and historic basilica at this civic center located at the juncture of the Mission, Castro, Lower Haight, and Noe Valley neighborhoods.

__EAT__ 

You’re spoiled for choices when it comes to superb pastries in the Mission District, home of the beloved bakery [__Tartine__](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/san-francisco/tartine-bakery), where you’ll find the city’s flakiest yet softest croissants. Head to Craftsman and Wolves for a quince éclair or handmade pop tarts stuffed with seasonally inspired fillings (roasted turkey and béchamel for Thanksgiving, for instance). 

__EXPLORE__ 

Order a Lyft ride to Balmy Street, where the walls dazzle with colorful murals. From whimsical (robots, Michael Jackson’s famous crotch grab) to political, to spiritual, this intimate alley is a genuine gallery of street art. If you happen to be here on Saturday, community arts organization [__Precita Eyes__](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/san-franciso/precita-eyes) runs mural tours that visit the Mission’s best frescos, including Balmy Street.

__PLAY__ 

Stock up on picnic provisions at [__Bi-Rite Market__](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/san-francisco/bi-rite-market), a remarkable neighborhood corner grocery doubling as the state’s ultimate gourmet catalog. (You know you’ve made it when your small-batch kombucha gets sold here.) Then head to [__Mission Dolores Park__](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/san-francisco/mission-dolores-park) and jostle for your own piece of green. This sunny park affords wide vistas of the city’s landscape, but most go there for the people watching.

__SHOP__ 

Return to Valencia, where car repair shops and dive bars have given way to businesses catering to bearded hipsters and dot-com hopefuls. Start at [__826 Valencia__](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/san-francisco/826-valencia-pirate-supply-store), a literacy and youth literary organization, which helps raise funds through its pirate supply store. You may not need a compass or a cutlass, but this Wunderkammer is a delightful experience in itself—and right in the middle of what might be the most eclectic stretch of shops in San Francisco.

__EAT__ 

There’s nothing lazy about [__Lazy Bear__](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/san-francisco/lazy-bear), a pop-up supper club that’s now a brick-and-mortar Mission business. The 40-seat restaurant features a visually enticing American prix fixe menu of 12-18 courses like smoked octopus with marigold petals or medallion of spring lamb in rhubarb rosemary sauce. 


[#image: /photos/548b61d1860c74c1162c917e]|||
The Interval
|||





##DAY 3: Outer Sunset and the Coast

Visitors to San Francisco tend to focus on the Bay, but the city has a long stretch of Pacific Coast popular with daredevil surfers and kite enthusiasts. During the Dungeness crab season (November through spring), you’ll also see amateur anglers casting crab cages and fishing poles alongside wetsuit-clad swimmers. 

__PLAY__ 

For that obligatory Golden Gate Bridge photo op, head over to [__Golden Gate Promenade__](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/san-francisco/golden-gate-promenade) and trace the shoreline. It’s popular among locals for a good reason.

Cycle or walk the entire length of the [__Golden Gate Park__](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/san-francisco/golden-gate-park) from the ocean toward the city, and you might happen up on a herd of buffalo by Spreckels Lake, or the immaculately manicured Japanese garden. Don’t miss the [__California Academy of Sciences__](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/san-francisco/california-academy-of-science), which has its own mini rainforest and aquarium. If you’re here late on a Thursday evening, make sure to swing by the Academy’s Nightlife, the city’s brainiest date night with DJs spinning ambient tunes. 

__EAT__ 

Settle on a parklet driftwood bench and have breakfast of sugary cinnamon toast, young coconut juice, and espresso drinks at the tiny [__Trouble Coffee & Coconut Club__](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/san-francisco/trouble-coffee-and-coconut-club). This neighborhood café is Outer Sunset’s prime meeting point.

Stop for lunch or dinner at the newly expanded and renovated [__Outerlands__](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/san-francisco/outerlands), where chef Greg Kuzia-Carmel serves dishes like cast iron grilled cheese and bacon vinaigrette-drizzled charred Brussels sprouts.

__DRINK__ 

Opened in June, [__The Interval__](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/san-francisco/the-interval) is a relatively well-kept secret—for now. The high-ceiling space is lined with thousands of books, giving this café/bar the feel of a gentleman scientist’s lair, complete with custom sounds designed by Brian Eno. The extensive drinks menu includes entire sections dedicated to martinis and daiquiris, as well as alcohol-free libations using local Samovar tea.

__EAT__ 

Return to the city center for dinner at the newly opened [__Game__](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/san-francisco/game), a restaurant specializing in wild food (think roasted venison with king trumpet, elk burgers, curried Monterey squid), located—appropriately—on Bush Street, in an intimate setting lightened with whimsical paintings of animal heads juxtaposed with human bodies

__STAY__

[__Hotel Vitale__](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/san-francisco/hotel-vitale--san-francisco) boasts stunning Bay Bridge views and a penthouse spa with rooftop soaking tubs. Meanwhile, the 336-room [__Ritz-Carlton, San Francisco__](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/san-francisco/ritz-carlton--san-francisco) looks fresher than ever, thanks to its current $27 million facelift.

eat.dek: Forget In-N-Out and Umami Burger. Those burgers are for tourists. When in San Francisco, get your burger fix at ROAM Burger.
eat.seoTitle: Skip In-N-Out. This is Where to Get Your Burgers on the West Coast
eat.seoDescription: Forget In-N-Out and Umami Burger. Those burgers are for tourists. When in San Francisco, get your burger fix at ROAM Burger.

eat.body:
[#image: /photos/53da95666dec627b149f45f4]||||||

When a burger-and-fry hankering strikes, San Franciscans leave In-N-Out Burger and Umami to the tourists. Instead, locals get their fix at [ROAM Artisan Burgers](http://www.roamburgers.com), which, in name alone, just sounds way more “San Francisco” right off the bat. ROAM keeps with all the traditional fast food concepts we all love—instant gratification counter service, inexpensive prices, and burgers that come packaged in those awesome paper wrappers. But SFers prefer ROAM above all the other California-based burger chains for overall tastiness and quality of ingredients.











For example, those bigger-than-your-head milkshakes are made with delicious local dairy products from [Strauss Family Creamery](http://strausfamilycreamery.com/). We’re not talking just about your standard vanilla shake, either—ROAM shakes come in salted caramel, coconut, or coffee made with cult favorite [Blue Bottle Coffee](http://www.bluebottlecoffee.com/). If you crave a soda with your burger, ROAM offers housemade options in seasonal flavors like prickly pear and blood orange—not to mention kombucha, wine, and beer too.



But enough about beverages: In the burger department, the offerings are oh-so-California. If you’re not into 100 percent grass-fed beef, you can swap in free-range turkey, bison, elk, ostrich, or an organic veggie patty—and opt to get any of these atop a gluten-free bun or a lettuce wrap instead. Pickles are made in-house, and other “standard” add-ons are taken up a notch: think aged cheeses, a choice between watercress or butter lettuce, a mound of oil and vinegar slaw, or an organic free-range egg.







Last but not least, there are three kinds of fries to suit your fancy: classic russet, sweet potato, or the elusive zucchini shoestring. Why choose? Order the Fry-Fecta—a hefty basket of all three. Best. Burger spot. Ever. _(1785 Union Street or 1923 Fillmore Street; [www.roamburgers.com](http://roamburgers.com))_

[#image: /photos/53e2f08fdddaa35c30f65895]||||||

There’s a reason San Francisco isn’t known as the city that never sleeps: Locals prefer to take advantage of early mornings in the picturesque Bay Area, spending time hiking, biking, or boating. But thanks to a crop of new restaurants and bars, night owls can rest assured that there’s plenty to eat, drink, and do into the wee hours of the morning.







**A Classic Bar Gets a Modern Update at Tosca Cafe**



 Celeb chef duo April Bloomfield and Ken Friedman (of NYC’s Spotted Pig and the John Dory) resurrected this historic 93-year-old bar with a revamped food and [cocktail menu](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/01/cool-cocktail-toca-san-francisco). Bloomfield puts a seasonal spin on Italian plates both small and large, including a pickly, piquant giardiniere, rustic meatballs and red sauce, and tuna conserva with radishes and bergamot. As you nosh, take in the lovingly restored details, such as vintage murals and straw-cased Chianti bottles._ 242 Columbus Ave; 415-986-9651, [toscacafesf.com](http://www.toscacafesf.com)._







**Refined Bar Bites from an Award-Winning Chef at Alta**



 Though James Beard Award–winning chef Daniel Patterson’s new joint seems exclusive (it’s located behind an unmarked door), the restaurant is as warm and convivial as a neighbor’s house. Though the fare here is relatively casual, Patterson’s flair for creativity is on display and the late-night menu (served until 2am) is as inventive as what you’d sample at dinner. The crunchy, chicharrone-like beef tendon puffs are highly addictive, and worth the trip alone. _1420 Market St; 415-590-2585, [altaca.co](http://www.altaca.co)_.







**Pair Mini-Golf With Comfort Food at Urban Putt**



 Putt-putt and beer isn’t a new pairing, but this brand-new mini-golf bar (which stays open until 2am) has a hyperlocal bent: Each of its 14 holes was developed with the help of local artists and engineers, and incorporates mechanical elements. A few even take the form of pint-sized SF landmarks: a reproduction of the [Painted Ladies](http://www.sanfrancisco.travel/icons/Alamo-Square--the-Painted-Ladies.html) actually skaes during a simulated earthquake. Upstairs, the 70-seat dining room that serves comfort food crowd-pleasers like plump fried chicken thighs. And on either floor, enjoy a cocktail program by Scott Baird and Josh Harris, the mixology legends behind the always-packed Trick Dog and Comstock Saloon. _1096 South Van Ness Ave; 415-341-1080, [urbanputt.com](http://www.urbanputt.com)._







**Sample Spicy Curries and Crab Noodles at Kin Khao**



 The buzz is high for this idiosyncratic Thai joint: Opened by restaurant-biz newcomer [Pim Techamuanvivit](http://kinkhao.com/staff/pim-techamuanvivit/) (who’s Bangkok born and bred), the eatery features riffs on traditional Thai dishes like rabbit curry and chicken fat rice. Tucked into the bottom floor of the Parc 55 hotel—until recently, something of a restaurant desert—the bare-bones dining room makes for an excellent last stop. Dishes like crab rice noodles and duck-egg salad are ideal drinking food—but the spice-averse should be careful, since many dishes are delectably lip-tingling. _Parc 55 Hotel, enter at the corner of Mason St and Ellis St; 415-362-7456, [kinkhao.com](http://www.kinkhao.com)._











**More travel ideas in San Francisco:**







[The Perfect Weekend in San Francisco](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/03/weekend-activities-and-events-san-francisco-california)







[This New San Francisco Restaurant Has Beautiful Pizzas and 14 Kinds of Prosciutto](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/03/san-francisco-restaurant-la-nebbia-pizzas-prosciutto)







[Take a Tour of San Francisco's Best Street Art, and Then Make Your Own (Legally)](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/04/san-francisco-coolest-street-art)

eat.dek: From chocolate beer ice cream to made-from-scratch s'mores, this is why everyone leaves their heart in San Francisco.
eat.hed: A Chocolate Lover's Guide to San Francisco

items.title: [Chocolate Beer Ice Cream](http://www.humphryslocombe.com/www.humphryslocombe.com/Home.html)
items.caption: This might seem like the average Mission District ice creamery when you walk through the door, but one peek into the freezer case will have you eating your words. Their inventive, chocolate-based flavor offerings change regularly, but the two currently on offer are some of the most delicious we've tried. One is made with a chocolate porter from Almanac brewing company and stuffed with dark chocolate chips, while the second flavor is made with milk chocolate and malt. Get this combo atop a cone, which many say are the best in the city.

items.title: [Chocolate Croissant Stack ](http://www.craftsman-wolves.com)
items.caption: Trying to choose just one chocolate treat at this super hip bakery-cafe is, well, torture. Let us explain: Their version of San Francisco's signature sourdough bread is laced with cocoa and chocolate chips. Similarly, their breakfast carrot cake muffin comes flavored with cocoa and features a crumb topping, while their "traditional" croissant is shaped like a towering square and stuffed with chocolate (and topped with it). Need we say more?

items.title: [Chocolate Truffle Tart ](ttps://www.miette.com/mailorder/confections/fleur-de-sel-caramels)
items.caption: Though many locals choose Miette for its pretty packaging and whimsical treats, the shop’s filled with glass candy jars and perfectly piped cupcakes—the chocolate ganache tart alone shows this bakery is worth its gourmet salt. The shop makes 20 gallons of ganache each week, using it as a glaze for eclairs and a filling for macarons too, but these tiny tarts pack the highest concentration of it per bite. The French sea salt finish puts it over the top. Splitting one is the best kind of messy.

items.title: [The House S’Mores](http://www.dandelionchocolate.com)
items.caption: That whole campfire thing doesn’t happen at Dandelion Chocolate, but you won’t miss it much when you’re digging into their signature s’mores. Nothing comes out of a plastic bag or paper sleeve here: graham crackers are made from scratch and have a perfectly crumbly consistency, marshmallows receive an ideal amount of char, and the chocolate is made from hand-roasted, smoke-dried cocoa beans from Papua New Guinea that are naturally smoky. Plus, each s’more is toasted to order.

items.title: [Chocolate Shake](http://www.stfrancisfountainsf.com)
items.caption:
There are plenty of places to get a milkshake in San Francisco, but none half as charming inside as St. Francis Fountain. This old-fashioned diner and dessert bar is the real deal: Established in 1918, it’s the city’s oldest soda shop. While the menu offers no shortage of throwback chocolate offerings, like black and white shakes, egg creams, and hot fudge sundaes, the chocolate milkshake is a perfect dose of nostalgia, with chocolate ice cream, a hefty dose of chocolate syrup, and a splash of milk. Thanks to the two straws, it’s also perfect for sharing—not that you'll want to.




**More on San Francisco food:**




[Skip In-N-Out. This is Where to Get Your Burgers on the West Coast](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/01/roam-burger-san-francisco )[](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/01/iron-steam-espresso-bar-san-francisco )




[The One Drink You Should Have in SF and Where to Get It](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/01/iron-steam-espresso-bar-san-francisco )







[These Food Photos Will Make You Want to Book a Ticket to SF, Now](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/10/what-to-eat-san-francisco-fall-restaurants-fog-city-ame-rich-table_slideshow_item0_1)

featuredPlays.name: Exploratorium
featuredPlays.description: Unlike the exhibits at most museums, those at the Exploratorium are designed for tinkering with, climbing on, and crawling through. Kid-proof and adult friendly fun for the whole family, come to the Exploratorium to experience science and perception through play. Open Tuesdays through Sundays 10 am to 5 pm.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: Explore science through hands-on play at this experiential museum.

featuredPlays.name: Ferry Building Marketplace
featuredPlays.description: The iconic whitewashed Ferry Building, standing proud at the water's edge behind a row of statuesque palms, is a sight in itself. Situated on a sunny patch of the Embarcadero, this sweeping, huge building opened in 1898 as a water-transportation hub for the city, but these days it's a foodie mecca. Weekdays, it draws Financial District types for lunch on the patio at MarketBar and arty freelancers skateboarding or chowing down at Gott's Roadside, a 1950s-style all-natural burger joint that also serves nouveau diner food like pistachio-espresso milk shakes. Locals come for loaves straight from the oven at Acme Bread, one of the best bakeries in the Bay Area; succulent, locally harvested oysters from Hog Island Oyster Company; and artisanal cakes from Miette, a tiny pâtisserie selling exquisite macaroons and cannelés (their candy shop in Hayes Valley is likewise a local favorite). Saturday mornings are prime time to shop for farmstead cheeses, heirloom tomatoes, homemade jams, herbs, and flowers at the Ferry Plaza Farmers Market (open Tuesdays and Saturdays year-round, Thursdays and Sundays seasonally). The focus is, of course, on local, seasonal, and sustainable produce, with hard-to-find fare like wild nettles, fresh lavender, and free-range eggs in shades of mint and baby blue.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: Once San Francisco's water-transportation center, these days it's a foodie's mecca.

featuredPlays.name: de Young Museum
featuredPlays.description: Damaged by an earthquake in 1989, the de Young opened its latest modern, angular building—clad in a perforated copper skin—in Golden Gate Park in October 2005. When it debuted, the local response was extreme: residents either loved it or hated it. Now they've mostly accepted it, thanks in large part to consistently stellar programming, lively monthly parties, and some of the city's best views. The permanent collection comprises American, African, Oceanic, American Indian, New Guinea, Maori, and Filipino art and includes some notable works by Frida Kahlo. The below-ground galleries house temporary exhibitions of varying quality. It's free to head to the top of the nine-story observation tower, where clear city days offer stunning views. On Friday evenings, the museum stays open late for its "Friday Nights at the de Young" program, when you can sip cocktails as you take in anything from poetry to performance art.
geoTags: North America/United States/Bay Area/California/San Francisco/Inner Richmond
featuredPlays.shortDescription: The de Young promises consistently stellar programming, lively monthly parties, and panoramic views.

featuredPlays.name: Golden Gate Park

address.street: Enter at La Playa St. and Lincoln Way

featuredPlays.description: When New York City opened Central Park in 1857, San Francisco was like, “Hey, we want one of those!” Shortly thereafter, Scotsman John McLaren got to work on this massive park, built improbably on barren sand dunes. Stretching more than three miles from Haight-Ashbury to the Pacific Ocean, Golden Gate is lush with woodlands, flowers, meadows, and lakes. There’s also plenty to do: Check out the indoor rainforest at the Academy of Sciences, have a cuppa Buddha-side at the Japanese Tea Garden, hike up Strawberry Hill, or see a herd of bison at the Buffalo Paddock.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: Golden Gate is lush with woodlands, flowers, meadows and lakes.

featuredStays.name: Ritz-Carlton, San Francisco
featuredStays.description: Union Square, Chinatown, and Nob Hill are all walkable from this century-old white neoclassical Nob Hill landmark with Ionic columns, once the headquarters of a life insurance company. Traditional rooms marry walnut, mahogany, and local artwork. Dishes at the Lobby Lounge include a salmon BLT, fennel-pollen salmon, and Brandt Farms New York strip. Rooms feature a palette of yellows and taupes, while suites showcase soft blues and golds. Chinoiserie cabinets, European-influenced bed chests, and intricately detailed bedside tables and headboards. The Club Level, where guests have their own business lounge and get snacks, hors d’oeuvres, and drinks throughout the day, kicks it up a notch.
featuredStays.shortDescription: Century-old, white neoclassical Nob Hill landmark with Ionic columns.

featuredStays.name: St. Regis San Francisco
featuredStays.description: A "delicious urban oasis" awaits guests at this 40-story building with hotel rooms and private residences near the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and Union Square. "The best use of space I’ve ever seen in a hotel room" is achieved through a recessed closet system concealing shelving, drawers, a minibar, and a CD/DVD player; rooms also feature Bella Crema marble, leather walls, and Mozambique wood doors. The lobby has a 16-foot open fireplace, Zebrano wood, and Italian travertine flooring. Breakfast at Vitrine uses seasonal, local ingredients to create items like German caramelized-peach pancakes; at lunch, order an organic beef burger. "They know how to treat their guests."
featuredStays.shortDescription: A "delicious urban oasis" awaits guests at this 40-story building.

"The best use of space I’ve ever seen in a hotel room" is achieved through a recessed closet system concealing shelving, drawers, a minibar, and a CD/DVD player; rooms also feature Bella Crema marble, leather walls, and Mozambique wood doors. The lobby has a 16-foot open fireplace, Zebrano wood, and Italian travertine flooring.
