fields.title: St. Regis, San Francisco

featuredStays.name: Mandarin Oriental, San Francisco
featuredStays.description: A total makeover of the first Mandarin Oriental property in the United States (opened in 1987), with 158 redesigned rooms and lobby, a brand-new spa, and a reimagined restaurant in the Financial District.
featuredStays.shortDescription: Newly reopened, with reimagined rooms, spa, and restaurant.

featuredStays.name: Hotel Vitale
featuredStays.description: The most striking aspect of Joie de Vivre’s first luxury property might be the rooftop deck’s million-dollar view of San Francisco Bay. Indeed, the disparate halves of the city converge at this 200-room hotel on the revitalized Embarcadero waterfront. For corporate types, complimentary car service and a cozy penthouse-level spa supply the requisite convenience and coddling. For earthy types, lavender-scented hallways are lit by leaf-patterned panels that suggest forest canopies, and complimentary yoga classes are held in the penthouse studio. In a city with dozens of outstanding dining options, the Americano restaurant has itself become a destination.
featuredStays.shortDescription: The disparate halves of the city converge at this 200-room hotel on the Embarcadero waterfront.

[#image: /photos/5429c31c8614701924e12be5]||||||





Here's yet another reason to visit San Francisco: The City By the Bay has just launched [a free Wi-Fi network](http://time.com/3453871/google-gives-san-francisco-free-wi-fi-in-public-places/) that extends through many public spaces, such as parks and museums.And it's not the only urban center jumping on the Wi-Fi bandwagon. [Lothian Buses](http://lothianbuses.com/news/article/Free-wi-fi-on-all-Lothian-Buses), the main public bus company in Edinburgh, Scotland, began rolling out free Wi-Fi on its buses this summer. That means visitors to Edinburgh, its airport, and the surrounding area can plot their routes on Google Maps or browse Yelp restaurant recommendations without having to sacrifice transit time.

But you don't have to go to Silicon Valley or Scotland [if you want free Wi-Fi access](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-04-09/free-food-travelers-lists-most-wanted-hotel-amenities) while you travel. Here's a list of other towns and cities who also have the hookup.

##TEL AVIV

Tech-obsessed Israelis are behind the free Wi-Fi access throughout all of Tel Aviv and the port city of Jaffa. Thanks to their "free_tlv" network, you can check work emails while drinking *limonanas* (blended mint lemonade drinks) on the beach. 

##NEW YORK CITY

The city that never sleeps is also a city that never turns off its iPhone. The rapidly growing network of places in the city with free Wi-Fi includes many public parks, subway stations, and outdoor spaces like the Brooklyn Bridge. Check out the city's [official Wi-Fi map](http://www.nycgo.com/articles/wifi-in-nyc/) before your trip.

##SEOUL

South Korea claims to be the most wired country in the world, and it's in the process of bringing free Wi-Fi to a whopping 10,000 hotspots throughout Seoul by 2015. Those locations include Itaewon Airport, many public parks and municipal sites, and the tourist-packed Gangnam neighborhood.

##BANGALORE

Bangalore recently became the first city in India to open up free Wi-Fi hotspots. For now, you can only get three hours of free access, but city officials have plans to expand the options and the coverage area. Getting onto the network also gives you the chance to download tourist-friendly apps about parking spaces and the closest places to drop off garbage.

##BOSTON

Lots of places have free Wi-Fi, but only Boston has “wicked” free Wi-Fi. Beantown Mayor Martin J. Walsh has been trying to bring more tech entrepreneurs to the city, and his free Wi-Fi initiative was a major part of the platform. The coverage area includes popular tourist spots like Faneuil Hall, Hyde Park, and Boston Common.

##OSAKA

Not only does Osaka, Japan, have a comprehensive free Wi-Fi network—it also has a mascot, Osaka Bob, a little boy who helps people figure out how to use the system. The city has two connection choices: Osaka Free Wi-Fi, which is unlimited but requires re-logging in every half hour, and a “Lite” option that gives one hour of access per day.

##PERTH

Australia's fourth-largest city is leading the charge in free Wi-Fi Down Under. The "Perth Wi-Fi" network covers most of the city center, and you can stay online for free—although you may have to periodically re-connect to the network.

##BARCELONA

Barcelona loves futuristic architecture, so it's no shock that the city also loves embracing technology. Its expansive free Wi-Fi network has more than 700 hotspots, which blankets the city with free internet.

fields.name: Lilit Marcus
fields.shortBio: Lilit Marcus is *Condé Nast Traveler*'s contributing digital editor.
fields.bio: Lilit Marcus is a Brooklyn-based journalist and *Condé Nast Traveler*'s contributing digital editor. Her first book, *Save the Assistants: A Guide for Surviving and Thriving in the Workplace,* was published by Hyperion. Lilit's favorite destinations include Lisbon, Tel Aviv, Nashville, and Mexico City. Her work has also appeared in The Wall Street Journal, Glamour, The Guardian, Cosmopolitan, and The New York Observer.

related.hed: Made Here, Buy Here: What You Can’t Leave San Francisco Without
related.dek: How can you navigate the universe of things to buy in San Francisco, a city where creativity and entrepreneurial chops are pretty much prerequisites to residency? You can start with this list.

items.title: Spark + Pepper Cuff
items.caption:
I’ve been severely jewelry compromised for the last several years, what with small humans tugging on every loose chain or dangling earring adorning my person. Meredith Peck of [Spark + Pepper](http://sparkandpepper.com/) designs durable pieces that can withstand even the most determined little fingers while maintaining a look of elegance and simplicity. Born in Korea, raised in New Jersey and now deeply embedded in San Francisco, Peck’s esthetic is at once universal and unique. She carves each piece in wax, then casts in brass and recycled bronze, using occasional accents of linen and silk and gold. See her bracelets and more at Gather, a terrific store in boutique-heavy Hayes Valley that features a culled selection of handcrafted accessories, clothing, and home goods.  

__Buy it at:__ [Gather](http://www.gathersf.com/), 541 Octavia Street; $75.

items.title: California Gold from San Francisco Mead Company
items.caption:
The word *mead* may conjure images of hairy-knuckled Vikings gulping from chalices, but husband-and-wife team Sarah Jones and Oren Benary are persuading San Franciscans to consider this ancient beverage anew. Using wild honey from a queen breeder in Mendocino and organic orange blossom honey from the Central Valley, the couple have crafted “California Gold,” a dry honey wine redolent of cedar, pine, and citrus, reflecting the home turf of the bees. Served chilled, it’s a versatile accompaniment much in the way of a medium-bodied white wine. Swing by the Bayview warehouse on a Saturday to sample their other creations: a Blackberry Mead perfect for lazy summer sipping, a cider-mead blend made with local Gravenstein apples, and a forthcoming coffee mead made in partnership with the terrific SF-based Ritual Roasters; otherwise pick up a bottle at Bi-Rite Grocery or Rainbow Grocery.  

__Buy it at:__ [San Francisco Mead Company](http://www.sfmead.com/), 1180 Shafter Ave.

items.title: Elizabeth Street: “Street Gloss”
items.caption:
Kelly Crispin, the owner and creative force behind [Elizabeth Street Cosmetics](http://www.elizabethstreetcosmetics.com/), understands that for many women, swiping on a bit of gloss is a simple, essential pleasure, and she’s determined to provide San Franciscans with a bevy of shades reflecting the varied personalities of the city’s neighborhoods. She names each new shade for the street that inspired it—Valencia is a creamy pure red, Golden Gate a sheer gold shimmer—and she takes great care when formulating her paraben-free products, sourcing all ingredients from Canada and infusing them with antioxidants and a hint of vanilla. Bring the streets of San Francisco home on your lips by picking up a prettily packaged tube.  

__Buy it at:__ [Rare Device](http://raredevice.net/), 600 Divisadero Street; $24.

items.title: Scabby Robot Wedge Bag
items.caption:
This bag, like most of [Jill Harrell](https://www.etsy.com/people/scabbyrobot)’s leather goods, is as functional as it is gorgeous. With a background in industrial design, Jill approaches her work with a keen eye on efficiency, durability and grace; her supple leather bags, clutches and laptop cases are three dimensional sculptures, each cut, sewn and finished with her own hands.   

__Buy it at:__ Antelope, 973 Valencia Street; $188.

items.title: Yosh Perfume
items.caption:
[Yosh Han](http://www.eaudeyosh.com/) is one of the more established independent perfumers in the country—her fragrances are available at Barney’s and she's creating a forthcoming “California Aromascapes” line for Anthropologie—but only in San Francisco can you visit Yosh’s apartment for a psychic reading and possibly have a custom perfume crafted just for you. I met Yosh at a local day spa, and whether through her famed clairvoyance or complicated olfactory talent, she was able to sniff my skin and match me to two perfumes: Sottile—a gentle, classic scent of tea rose and lily of the valley that cultivates the feminine, reflective self—and Ginger Ciao, a subtle spicy fragrance with sandalwood, ginger, and basil. Yosh says each perfume has its own corresponding chakra and numerological value and can have a potent impact on how the wearer approaches the world.

__Buy it at:__ [Dish](http://www.dishboutique.com/), 541 Hayes Street; or contact Yosh directly to schedule an appointment for a custom blend, 415-626-5385.

items.title: Cookies from Mariposa Bakery
items.caption:
More than a decade ago, [Mariposa Bakery](http://www.mariposabaking.com/) founder Patti Furey Crane found herself pregnant and hungry for quality gluten-free baked goods. Frustrated by the options available, she set about making her own, not relenting until she’d reached the highest standard of chew and taste without compromising on ingredients. While Mariposa’s certified green bakery and storefront is worth a trip across the Bay Bridge to Oakland, you can find a broad selection of their pastries at their San Francisco kiosk in the Ferry Building Marketplace, which should be a required stop for any hungry San Francisco visitor. Eat a lunch of roasted veggie pizza and then pick up a box of buttery Viennese tea cookies or herbed crackers for the trip home. 

__Buy it at:__ Mariposa Bakery, 1 Ferry Building

items.title: Dandelion Chocolates
items.caption:
Do not leave the Ferry Building Marketplace without stopping off for a sample or a few dozen bars of this remarkable and beautifully packaged chocolate. [Dandelion](http://www.dandelionchocolate.com/) is one of a handful of bean-to-bar operations in California, and through the company’s careful, small-batched approach to fermentation, roasting and mixing, the humble cacoa bean is raised to its true potential. For a more intimate look at Dandelion’s craft, visit the factory at 714 Valencia Street and sip rich melted chocolate while watching the chocolate-making process underway.  

__Buy it at:__ [Dandelion Chocolates](http://www.dandelionchocolate.com/), 1 Ferry Building

related.socialTitle: 7 Things You Must Buy in San Francisco
related.socialDescription: How can you navigate the universe of things to buy in San Francisco, a city where creativity and entrepreneurial chops are pretty much prerequisites to residency? You can start with this list.

related.dek: Though many view it as a layover city, Oakland is a thriving shopping destination in its own right. Here are some of the best places to check out if you're in the East Bay.

items.title: This Is Oakland
items.caption: When my friend Melissa Davis released her latest guidebook, [This Is Oakland](http://www.thisisoaklandbook.com/), I was surprised to discover that I hadn't visited nearly half of the incredible restaurants, cafes, specialty stores, and boutiques she profiled. (After all, I had relocated to the East Bay from New York nearly four years ago.) So with book in hand, and with the extra bonus of having Davis as my personal travel guide, I went on a mission to explore what this vibrant, culture-rich city has to offer. Here are ten of my new favorite local haunts.

items.title: [Oaktown Spice Shop](https://squareup.com/market/oaktown-spice-shop)
items.caption: Cooking enthusiasts and spice geeks travel near and far to visit Oaktown Spice Shop for its extensive inventory of high quality herbs and spices. Owner John Beaver sources spices from all over the world and hand grinds distinct mixes. The Persian Lime Curry Rub, Moroccan Style Fish Tagine, and Cyprus Citron Lemon Flake Sea Salt are best sellers and not to be missed. *(530 Grand Ave.; 510-201-5400)*

items.title: [Esqueleto](http://www.shopesqueleto.com/)
items.caption: You'll think you've struck gold when you step inside Esqueleto, jewelry designer Lauren Wolf's white-washed boutique. In addition to her eponymous jewelry collection, Lauren curates an incredible selection of locally sources textiles, objects, and art, and stunning jewelry from various designers like Bliss Lau, Rebecca Overmann, All For The Mountain, and Mociun. *(482 49th St., ste. A; 510-629-6216)*

You'll think you've struck gold when you step inside Esqueleto, jewelry designer Lauren Wolf's white washed, adobe-like boutique. In addition to her eponymous jewelry collection, Lauren curates the most incredible selection of locally sources textiles, objects, and art, and stunning jewelry from various designers like Bliss Lau, Rebecca Overmann, All For The Mountain, and Mociun. *(482 49th Street, Suite A; 510-629-6216)*

items.title: [Loot Antiques](http://www.lootantiques.com/)
items.caption: Antiques collector and floral designer Ron Morgan is a bona fide treasure hunter. Little vignettes in his inspiring shop are styled with period furniture, antique lighting, modern objects, and vintage china and tableware. *(5391 College Ave.; 510-547-1400)*

items.title: [Issues](http://www.issuesshop.com/)
items.caption: This tiny shop carries a huge, comprehensive selection of rare and hard to locate domestic and international glossies. In addition to Issues' vast assortment of magazines, you can find handpicked vinyl records, a selection of used books, and handy little notebooks. *(20 Glen Ave.; 510-652-5700)*

items.title: [Temescal Alley Barber Shop](http://temescalalleybarbershop.tumblr.com/)
items.caption: Most days, a line forms outside of this old-school barber shop, which prides itself on the craft of barbering and personable service. It's an experience from start to finish—especially when you're offered a shot of whiskey to help ease the wait. *(470 49th St.; 510-761-5074)*

items.title: [Umami Mart](http://umamimart.com/)
items.caption: If you're looking to dress up your bar cart, Umami Mart is the place to check out. The minimalist store specializes in hard to find, high end Japanese barware, like gold-plated cocktail shakers, hand-etched mixing glasses, and an interesting selection of bitters and syrups. *(815 Broadway; 510-250-9559)*

items.title: [Cosecha](http://www.cosechacafe.com/)
items.caption: Chef Dominca Rice, a Chez Panisse veteran, opened her farm to table cafe to meld traditional Mexican techniques and flavors with California ingredients. The tortillas are handmade, the pork belly is braised to perfection, the horchata latte is delightful, and the seasonal salads are bright with flavor. *(907 Washington St.; 510-452-5900)*

items.title: [Donut Savant](http://www.donutsavant.com/)
items.caption: Donut hole lovers will truly appreciate Donut Savant's bite-sized versions of glazed, chocolate-covered, and cinnamon sugar donuts. With unique flavors like salted maple and Irish Whiskey-filled chocolate donuts, you won't need an excuse to try them all. *(1934 Broadway; 206-409-3770)*

items.title: [Atomic Garden](http://atomicgardenoakland.com/)
items.caption: Sustainability and a love for all things hand-crafted were the inspiration behind Atomic Garden, a treasure trove of home goods, organic clothing, and globally sourced knickknacks. The selection is diverse, and includes goodies like rugs made of vintage saris, aromatic body balms, or hand-stitched dolls. *(5453 College Ave.; 510-923-0543)*

items.title: [Mercy Vintage Now](https://www.mercyvintage.com/)
items.caption: Mercy Vintage is one of the best secondhand shops in the Bay Area, offering old-school treasures like dresses from the 1940s or pieces of costume jewelry. Prices are also extremely reasonable. *(4188 Piedmont Ave.; 510-654-5599)*

fields.shortBio: Erica Chan Coffman is the founder and editor in chief of [HonestlyWTF](http://honestlywtf.com/) and [HonestlyYUM](http://honestlyyum.com/).
fields.bio: Erica Chan Coffman is the editor in chief of [HonestlyWTF](http://honestlywtf.com/), a lifestyle blog with a global following. Beautifully curated stories covering style, art, travel, home decor, and DIY are awe-inspiring and inspirational. Erica also oversees [HonestlyYUM](http://honestlyyum.com/), a culinary destination for seasonal food and cocktail recipes and entertaining ideas. When she's not working from her home in Oakland, CA, she is globetrotting with her husband and toddler.

related.hed: The Perfect Day Trip from San Francisco: Healdsburg, Sonoma County
related.dek: Healdsburg, Sonoma County is only an hour's drive from San Francisco, but it feels worlds away with its sprawling wineries and cozy, small-town vibe. Here's what to do on a day trip up north.

related.socialTitle: The Perfect Day Trip from San Francisco: Healdsburg, Sonoma County
related.socialDescription: Healdsburg, Sonoma County is only an hour's drive from San Francisco, but it feels worlds away with its sprawling wineries and cozy, small-town vibe. Here's what to do on a day trip up north.
related.body:
[#image: /photos/53da8d09dcd5888e145bc04b]||||||

__WHY YOU’RE GOING:__ This beautiful and fun-loving town is shaping up to be Sonoma County’s darling. It's more than just wineries—though there's plenty of those. Healdsburg is filled with quiet, charming inns, excellent farm-fresh food, and a small but bustling city center. Plus, if you go this time of year, you'll get to enjoy the beauty of Sonoma County, sans summer crowds.



__WHAT TO DO:__ Indulge in some you time at [Honor Mansion](http://honormansion.com), a romantic little inn just ten minutes from the city center on foot. Book one of their beautiful cottages or suites, many of which boast fireplaces, indoor whirlpool tubs, and private outdoor patios, where you can enjoy the complimentary wine and appetizers you're offered every afternoon. You can participate in croquet and bocce games, if that's your style, or you can simply relax in an outdoor spa tub, perfect for stargazing._ (891 Grove St, 707-433-4722)_

[#image: /photos/53da8d096dec627b149f235e]||||||

You can't visit Healdsburg without stopping by at the airy, avant-garde housewares shop, restaurant, and culinary center that is [SHED](http://healdsburgshed.com). SHED somehow achieves an earthy-casual atmosphere in a 10,000 square foot contemporary prefab. Food offerings are a farm-to-table fairy tale: owners Cindy Daniel and Doug Lipton grow many of the ingredients on their nearby farm, and serve homemade hot chocolates, well-made cappuccinos, and even kombucha on tap. Check the events listings for food classes and talks on topics like soba making, beekeeping and butchery._ (25 North Street, 707-431-7433)_



Call ahead to score one of the cozy tables at [Scopa](http://scopahealdsburg.com). This unpretentious Italian spot gets the “keep it simple” thing just right with starters like grilled romaine doused in anchovy-garlic dressing—wonderfully salty and lightly warmed. Wood-fired pizzas have thin, blistered crusts that rival the real thing in Italy. And the house classic entree, the tomato-braised Nona’s Chicken, arrives in a mini cauldron with greens and still-bubbling, creamy polenta. _(109A Plaza Street, 707-433-5282)_

[#image: /photos/53da8d09dcd5888e145bc049]||||||

On a lazy afternoon, wander over to the refreshingly laid-back [Banshee Wines](http://bansheewines.com). The three thirty-something owners have re-imagined the stuffy tasting room set-up you’re used to seeing from the big name bottlers. Their quirky crash pad feels more living room than tasting room, with worn-in leather couches, retro textiles and open DJ policy (you can choose what to play from their vinyl collection). But don’t let all the youthfulness fool you: These guys are turning out some of the best wine in the west at their price point. _(325 Center Street; 707-395-0915)_







 **More on San Francisco:**



[San Francisco's Best Brunch. It's Worth the Two Hour Wait.](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/11/plow-san-francisco-best-brunch)







[Food Photos That'll Make You Want to Book a Ticket to San Francisco, Now](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/10/what-to-eat-san-francisco-fall-restaurants-fog-city-ame-rich-table)







[A San Francisco Art Gallery, Hidden in Plain Sight](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/09/san-francisco-art-gallery-pier-24)

cheatSheet.dek: Few cities in North America can claim as broad a palette of outdoor life so near its urban core. Whether it's hiking the East Bay hills; biking Mt Tam; hang gliding the Fort Funston cliffs; or wind surfing the choppy waters of the Bay, the scenery's stunning and the workouts are burningly real. Here are some of our favorites.

items.dek: They call its western slope "Castro Beach," but this park's spectacular city views lie to the east.
Fantastic views of the Golden Gate Bridge and Ocean Beach on this hike near iconic Cliff House.
One of the peninsula's best beaches, with stunning oceanside views of the Golden Gate Bridge.
The ride's nearly as spectacular as the charming waterside town of Sausalito itself.
California's version of the small, good life in a spectacular beach-bordered coastal town.
Some of the best hiking and biking in the US, rising dramatically from the Golden Gate.

cheatSheet.dek: It's often said — rightly — that San Francisco punches above its cultural weight class. The same is true of its history. Critical moments in the country's intellectual and artistic life haven't just passed through; they've started here, or reached critical mass here, or achieved here their definitive expression. It's a town of firsts and a town of mosts. Here's evidence.

items.dek: Come for regular movie screenings, sing-alongs, film festivals, private events, and fundraisers.
Pride is an annual parade and festival to celebrate the LGBT community.
Admire the WPA murals decorating the first floor and take the elevator to the top for the view.

Hop on the Powell-Hyde streetcar and explore the city’s rolling topography.
